lead_paragraph: For the accord to work, governments must resist ever more affordable fossil fuels in favor of policies that encourage and, in many cases, require the use of renewable energy sources.

byline.contributor: Keith Bradsher and Bill Vlasic contributed reporting.
byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and DIANE CARDWELL

snippet: For the accord to work, governments must resist ever more affordable fossil fuels in favor of policies that encourage and, in many cases, require the use of renewable energy sources.

headline.main: Climate Deal’s First Big Hurdle: The Draw of Cheap Oil
headline.print_headline: Climate Pact Put to Test by Drop in Price of Oil

abstract: Sweeping global agreement on cutting carbon emissions by embracing renewable energy sources is being tested by plummeting oil prices; officials in United States and China say they will remain steadfast in moving ahead with energy efficiency programs, which can be costly and unpopular, particularly in face of increasingly affordable fossil fuels.
